did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Rah For The Engineers! research material, 1921-1987
did.abstract: The bulk of this collection consists of correspondence, interviews, and reminiscences, with faculty, alumni, and students of the College of Engineering. The papers relate the personalities, projects, and growth of the College during its first century of existence. The majority of these materials were collected by McCormick between 1984 and 1986, and were used in his book Rah for the Engineers! research material

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: Rah For The Engineers! research materials(AZ 521). Special Collections, University of Arizona Libraries.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: James P. McCormick was born in 1911 and attended Northwestern University (PhD 1937). He was an English professor at Wayne State Univertsity, and, later, an administrator for Detroit Edison Company. He retired to Tucson in 1974 and accepted a position as adjunct professor of engineering at the University of Arizona.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into four series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The bulk of this collection consists of correspondence, interviews, and reminiscences, with faculty, alumni, and students of the College of Engineering. The papers relate the personalities, projects, and growth of the College during its first century of existence. The majority of these materials were collected by McCormick between 1984 and 1986, and were used in his book Rah For The Engineers! research material

Contains mostly personal reminiscences and interviews by McCormick of students, deans and faculty of the college from the 1920s to the 1980s. The narratives describe personal companionships, professional associations, relationships with the professors, financial and intellectual challenges to the students, and their evaluations of higher education.

did.unittitle: Correspondence and interviews with David Hall. 1982-1984

scopecontent.p: Mostly black and white photographs of activities, faculty, facilities, and students at the College. Of interest are several views, ca. 1920s, of the Saint Patrick's Day Parade, an annual outings sponsored by students.

Includes graphs, charts, speeches, memos, handwritten interviews, drafts of text, clippings, correspondence, and departmental reports, including "Academics in the College of Engineering," used in the preparation of the book Rah for the Engineers!
Corrected copy of Rah for the Engineers! with handwritten notes by McCormick to future researchers using his history.
